p: Fusion is promoted in conditions of nutrient scarcity and is thought to boost mitochondrial bioenergetics efficiency, whereas fission is favored when nutrients are not limited and results in increased nutrient storage, but conversely reduced bioenergetics efficiency ( Schrepfer and Scorrano, 2016). Mitochondrial fusion furthermore enables the exchange of mtDNA, metabolites, proteins, and lipids ( Pernas and Scorrano, 2016), whereas fission is not only associated with increased ROS production but also facilitates mitochondrial quality control (mitophagy) and mitochondrial distribution, for example, to match local energy demands ( Giacomello et al., 2020; Horn et al., 2020).
